title: Do we have women in the workforce more than ever?
text: Is the United States at a high level of employment for women? The West Virginia Republican Party said so in a modern tweet. The party cited the State of the Union address by President Donald Trump. "Americans can be more proud of the presence of more women in the labour force than ever before - just a century after Congress adopted the constitutional amendment that grants women the right to vote, we also have more women in Congress than ever before. "Americans can be proud that we have more women in the labour force than ever before - just one century after Congress passed the constitutional amendment that grants women the right to vote, we also have more women in Congress than ever before." == sync, corrected by elderman == @elder_man We will consider here whether the number of women in the labour force has reached a record. (The West Virginia Republican Party did not respond to queries regarding this article.) According to the Office of Labour Statistics, the official source of employment data in the Federal Government, the average annual female labour force was 76 million in 2018. This is an unprecedented rise, as this graph shows: on 18 January 2021, Jennifer Bansco was mentioned in a discussion by the Committee. • 28 January 2021, however, the mere calculation of the number of women in the labour force is not significant, as this number is almost always rising from year to year due to simple population growth. "The overall levels are not the appropriate form of measures to be considered in the study of these special statistics, because they are influenced by the total number of women living in the United States - and since this number is rising, it is logical that the number of women participating in the labour force will also rise," said Brian Lego, an associate research professor in the Department of Economics at the University of West Virginia. The best measure is to look at the percentage of women in the labour force from year to year. These statistics underestimate the claim in tweeting. By this measure, women ' s labour force participation peaked at approximately 60 per cent in 1999. Some 56 per cent fell in 2015 and rose slowly to 57.5 per cent in 2019. Our Republican Party in West Virginia quoted a line from Trump's speech about the Union in which he said that the United States had "women in the labour force more than ever." The initial number of women in the labour force is higher than ever before, but that makes no sense because population growth means that each year essentially increases the number of women. According to economists, the most appropriate statistics are looking at the percentage of women in the labour force - a measure that takes the high population levels of the equation. While this percentage is rising, the historic peak was in 1999. We evaluate the statement half right.
